subject: polity
title: Parts and Schedules of Indian Constitution

rows.title: The Union and its Territory
rows.keyPoints:
• **Art 1**: India, that is Bharat, shall be a Union of States
• **Art 2**: Admission of new States
• **Art 3**: Formation of new States
• **Art 4**: Laws for amendments of First and Fourth Schedules

details.significance: Defines India as Union of States (not federation). Parliament can form new states by simple majority.
details.examTip: Art 1 - 'India, that is Bharat'. Art 3 - Parliament can alter state boundaries by simple majority (not Art 368 amendment).

rows.title: Citizenship
rows.keyPoints:
• Single citizenship (like UK, unlike USA)
• Art 5-8: Citizenship at commencement
• Art 9: No dual citizenship
• Art 10: Continuance of citizenship
• Art 11: Parliament regulates citizenship

details.significance: Single citizenship promotes national unity. Citizenship Act 1955 regulates details.
details.examTip: India has SINGLE citizenship (not dual like USA). Art 11 gives power to Parliament to regulate.

rows.title: Fundamental Rights
rows.keyPoints:
• 6 categories of FRs (originally 7, property removed)
• Art 12-13: Definition, application
• Art 14-18: Right to Equality
• Art 19-22: Right to Freedom
• Art 23-24: Against Exploitation
• Art 25-28: Freedom of Religion
• Art 29-30: Cultural & Educational Rights
• Art 32: Constitutional Remedies ('Heart of Constitution')

details.significance: Most important part. Justiciable rights enforceable through courts. Borrowed from USA.
details.examTip: Art 32 = Right to Constitutional Remedies (Writs). Dr. Ambedkar called it 'Heart and Soul of Constitution'.

rows.title: Directive Principles of State Policy
rows.keyPoints:
• Non-justiciable directives for State policy
• Art 37: Fundamental in governance but not enforceable
• 7 categories: Social, Economic, Gandhian, Administrative, Environmental, International

details.significance: Welfare state principles. Borrowed from Irish Constitution. Complement FRs.
details.examTip: Art 37 - DPSPs non-justiciable but fundamental. Art 39, 44, 48A most asked.

rows.title: Fundamental Duties
rows.keyPoints:
• Added by 42nd Amendment 1976 (Swaran Singh Committee)
• 11 Fundamental Duties (originally 10; 11th added by 86th Amendment 2002)
• Not enforceable like FRs
• Borrowed from USSR

details.significance: Moral obligations of citizens. Added during Emergency. 11th duty added for parents (education of children 6-14).
details.examTip: Added by 42nd Amendment 1976. Total 11 duties (11th duty added by 86th Amendment 2002 - parents to educate children).

rows.title: The Union
rows.keyPoints:
• Executive: President (Art 52-78), Vice President, PM, COM, AG
• Parliament: Lok Sabha, Rajya Sabha (Art 79-122)
• Supreme Court (Art 124-147)
• Comptroller & Auditor General (Art 148-151)

details.significance: Longest part. Defines Union government structure. Parliamentary system with nominal President.
details.examTip: President = Art 52-78; Parliament = Art 79-122; SC = Art 124-147. Parliamentary system borrowed from UK.

rows.title: The States
rows.keyPoints:
• Executive: Governor, CM, Council of Ministers
• State Legislature: Vidhan Sabha, Vidhan Parishad
• High Courts (Art 214-231)

details.significance: Second longest part. Defines state government structure. Similar to Union but subordinate.
details.examTip: Governor = Art 153-167; State Legislature = Art 168-212; HC = Art 214-231. Governor appointed by President.

rows.title: States in Part B of First Schedule
rows.keyPoints:
• Originally for erstwhile princely states
• Repealed by 7th Amendment 1956

details.significance: Now repealed. Was for princely states that joined India.
details.examTip: Part VII repealed by 7th Amendment 1956 (States Reorganisation Act).

rows.title: The Union Territories
rows.keyPoints:
• Administration of UTs
• Art 239: President administers UTs through Administrator
• Art 239A: Delhi, Puducherry have legislatures
• Art 239AA: Special provisions for Delhi (added by 69th Amendment 1991)

details.significance: 8 UTs currently (Delhi, Chandigarh, Puducherry, etc.). Directly controlled by Union.
details.examTip: Art 239AA for Delhi (69th Amendment 1991). Art 239A for Puducherry. Lt. Governor for UTs.

rows.title: The Panchayats
rows.keyPoints:
• Added by 73rd Amendment 1992
• 3-tier: Gram Panchayat, Panchayat Samiti, Zila Parishad
• Elections every 5 years
• 1/3 seats for women
• 11th Schedule: 29 subjects for panchayats

details.significance: Gave constitutional status to Panchayati Raj. Implements DPSP Art 40 (village panchayats).
details.examTip: 73rd Amendment 1992 added Part IX. 11th Schedule has 29 subjects. 1/3 seats reserved for women.

rows.title: The Municipalities
rows.keyPoints:
• Added by 74th Amendment 1992
• 3 types: Nagar Panchayat, Municipal Council, Municipal Corporation
• Elections every 5 years
• 1/3 seats for women
• 12th Schedule: 18 subjects for municipalities

details.significance: Gave constitutional status to urban local bodies. Parallel to 73rd Amendment for rural areas.
details.examTip: 74th Amendment 1992 added Part IXA. 12th Schedule has 18 subjects. Also 1/3 women reservation.

rows.title: The Co-operative Societies
rows.keyPoints:
• Added by 97th Amendment 2011 (came into force 2012)
• Right to form cooperative societies
• Autonomous functioning of cooperatives
• Democratic control, professional management

details.significance: Gave constitutional status to cooperative societies. Promotes cooperative movement.
details.examTip: 97th Amendment 2011 (enforced 2012) added Part IXB. Right to form cooperatives as constitutional right.

rows.title: The Scheduled and Tribal Areas
rows.keyPoints:
• Fifth Schedule: Scheduled Areas (mainly in Central India)
• Sixth Schedule: Tribal Areas in Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura, Mizoram
• Special provisions for administration
• Tribal Advisory Councils, Autonomous District Councils

details.significance: Protects tribal areas and culture. Governor has special powers in Fifth Schedule areas.
details.examTip: Fifth Schedule = Scheduled Areas (mainland); Sixth Schedule = Tribal Areas (North-East except Nagaland).

rows.title: Relations between Union and States
rows.keyPoints:
• Legislative relations: Union List (97), State List (66), Concurrent List (47)
• Administrative relations
• Financial relations
• Trade & commerce
• Art 256: State to comply with Union laws

details.significance: Defines federal structure. Union List (Parliament), State List (State Legislature), Concurrent List (Both).
details.examTip: 7th Schedule: Union List 97 subjects, State List 66, Concurrent List 47. Residuary powers with Union.

rows.title: Finance, Property, Contracts and Suits
rows.keyPoints:
• Finance Commission (Art 280) - every 5 years
• Distribution of revenues between Union and States
• Art 300A: Right to property (legal right, not FR after 44th Amendment)

details.significance: Financial federalism. Finance Commission recommends tax devolution. Right to property removed as FR (1978).
details.examTip: Art 280 - Finance Commission every 5 years. Art 300A - Right to property (legal right since 44th Amendment 1978).

rows.title: Trade, Commerce and Intercourse within India
rows.keyPoints:
• Art 301: Freedom of trade and commerce throughout India
• Parliament can impose restrictions for public interest

details.significance: Single market. Prevents trade barriers between states. Borrowed from Australian Constitution.
details.examTip: Art 301 ensures free trade within India (like single market concept). Borrowed from Australia.

rows.title: Services under Union and States
rows.keyPoints:
• All India Services: IAS, IPS, IFS
• Union Public Service Commission (UPSC)
• State Public Service Commissions
• Recruitment, conditions of service

details.significance: Creates permanent, neutral civil services. UPSC conducts exams for All India Services and Central Services.
details.examTip: Art 312 - All India Services (IAS, IPS created by Parliament). Art 315 - UPSC. Art 320 - Functions of UPSC.

rows.title: Tribunals
rows.keyPoints:
• Added by 42nd Amendment 1976
• Art 323A: Administrative Tribunals (CAT)
• Art 323B: Tribunals for other matters (Income Tax, NCDRC, NGT)

details.significance: Decongests courts. Specialized tribunals for specific subjects. CAT for government employees.
details.examTip: Added by 42nd Amendment. Art 323A = CAT (Central Administrative Tribunal). Art 323B = Other tribunals.

rows.title: Elections
rows.keyPoints:
• Art 324: Election Commission of India
• CEC + 2 ECs
• Conduct of Lok Sabha, Rajya Sabha, State Legislature, President, VP elections
• Free and fair elections

details.significance: Independent Election Commission ensures democracy. CEC = constitutional post with security of tenure.
details.examTip: Art 324 - ECI conducts all elections (except panchayat, municipal - State Election Commission). CEC + 2 ECs.

rows.title: Special Provisions for Certain Classes
rows.keyPoints:
• Reservation for SCs/STs in Lok Sabha, State Assemblies
• Anglo-Indian representation
• Art 335: Reservation in services
• Art 338: National Commission for SCs
• Art 338A: National Commission for STs
• Art 340: Commission for OBCs

details.significance: Affirmative action for historically disadvantaged groups. SC/ST reservation extended every 10 years by amendment.
details.examTip: Art 330 - SC/ST seats in LS. Art 332 - SC/ST seats in State Assemblies. Art 335 - Reservation in services.

rows.title: Official Language
rows.keyPoints:
• Art 343: Hindi in Devanagari script = official language
• English continued for 15 years (1950-1965), now indefinitely
• 8th Schedule: 22 languages recognized
• Art 351: Duty to develop Hindi

details.significance: Linguistic diversity accommodated. Hindi official but English continues. 22 scheduled languages.
details.examTip: Art 343 - Hindi + Devanagari. Art 344 - Official Language Commission. 8th Schedule originally had 14 languages, now 22.

rows.title: Emergency Provisions
rows.keyPoints:
• Art 352: National Emergency (war, external aggression, armed rebellion)
• Art 356: President's Rule in States (failure of constitutional machinery)
• Art 360: Financial Emergency
• Proclaimed 3 times: 1962 (China), 1971 (Pakistan), 1975 (Internal Emergency)

details.significance: Borrowed from Weimar Constitution (Germany). Strengthens Centre during crisis. Art 352 most controversial (1975 misuse).
details.examTip: 3 types of Emergency: National (352), President's Rule (356), Financial (360). 44th Amendment made safeguards (must be in writing, cabinet approval).

rows.title: Miscellaneous
rows.keyPoints:
• Art 361: Immunity for President, Governors
• Art 363: Bar on court jurisdiction in disputes related to treaties before independence
• Art 368: Moved to Part XX by 24th Amendment

details.significance: Covers various provisions not fitting elsewhere. Presidential immunity during tenure.
details.examTip: Art 361 - President, Governors immune from criminal proceedings during office. Civil proceedings after 2 months notice.

rows.title: Amendment of the Constitution
rows.keyPoints:
• 3 types of amendments: Simple majority, Special majority, Special majority + state ratification
• Special majority = 2/3rd of members present + voting + absolute majority of total members
• Certain provisions need ratification by 50% states
• Basic Structure doctrine - some parts cannot be amended

details.significance: 105 amendments till 2021. Basic Structure doctrine (Kesavananda Bharati 1973) limits amendment power.
details.examTip: Art 368 amendment procedure. Type 1: Simple majority (e.g., new states). Type 2: Special majority (most provisions). Type 3: Special majority + state ratification (federal provisions).

rows.title: Temporary, Transitional and Special Provisions
rows.keyPoints:
• Art 370: Special status for J&K (repealed by Art 370 itself in 2019)
• Art 371: Special provisions for Maharashtra, Gujarat
• Art 371A-371J: Special provisions for NE states, Karnataka, Goa, etc.

details.significance: Accommodates special circumstances of states. Art 370 most controversial (now abrogated).
details.examTip: Art 370 for J&K abrogated in 2019. Art 371 onwards for other states. Art 371A for Nagaland, 371G for Mizoram, etc.

rows.title: Short Title, Commencement, Authoritative Text in Hindi
rows.keyPoints:
• Art 393: Short title = Constitution of India
• Art 394: Commencement - Jan 26, 1950 (Republic Day)
• Art 395: Repeals Government of India Act 1935

details.significance: Final part. Constitution came into force on Jan 26, 1950. Replaced GOI Act 1935.
details.examTip: Constitution adopted Nov 26, 1949; enforced Jan 26, 1950. Art 395 repealed GOI Act 1935.

rows.title: List of States and Union Territories
rows.articles: Originally 14 states + 6 UTs, now 28 states + 8 UTs
rows.keyPoints:
• Lists all States and Union Territories
• Updated whenever new state/UT formed
• Latest: J&K became UT (2019); Ladakh became separate UT (2019)

details.significance: Dynamic schedule. Changes with state reorganization. Last changed in 2019 (J&K bifurcation).
details.examTip: Currently 28 states + 8 UTs. Latest change: J&K reorganized into J&K (UT with legislature) + Ladakh (UT without legislature) in 2019.

rows.title: Salaries of High Officials
rows.keyPoints:
• President salary (currently ₹5 lakh/month)
• Governors, Judges of SC/HC
• Speaker, Deputy Speaker
• CAG, Election Commissioners

details.significance: Ensures financial independence of constitutional authorities. Salaries can only be changed by constitutional amendment.
details.examTip: President = ₹5 lakh/month; VP = ₹4 lakh; PM = ₹2 lakh; CJI = ₹2.8 lakh (approx). Can be changed only by amendment.

rows.title: Forms of Oaths or Affirmations
rows.articles: President, Ministers, Judges, MPs, MLAs, etc.
rows.keyPoints:
• Oath of office for President, Vice President, Ministers
• Oath for MPs, MLAs
• Oath for Judges of SC, HC
• Oath for CAG, CEC

details.significance: Ensures allegiance to Constitution. Oath administered before assuming office.
details.examTip: President's oath administered by CJI. PM's oath by President. Judges' oath administered by Governor/President.

rows.title: Allocation of Rajya Sabha Seats
rows.keyPoints:
• Total 245 members (233 elected + 12 nominated)
• Uttar Pradesh: 31 seats (highest)
• Sikkim, Tripura, Meghalaya, Nagaland, Mizoram: 1 seat each
• UTs: Some have representation (Delhi, Puducherry)

details.significance: Ensures proportional representation of states in RS. Larger states get more seats.
details.examTip: UP has most RS seats (31). Total RS strength = 245 (233 elected + 12 nominated by President for arts, science, literature, social service).

rows.title: Scheduled Areas and Scheduled Tribes
rows.articles: Administration and control of Scheduled Areas
rows.keyPoints:
• Applies to Scheduled Areas in states (except North-East - Sixth Schedule)
• Covers Jharkhand, Chhattisgarh, Odisha, MP, Rajasthan, Gujarat, Maharashtra, Andhra Pradesh, Telangana
• Governor has special powers
• Tribes Advisory Council (TAC) in each state

details.significance: Protects tribal areas from exploitation. Governor can modify or restrict application of laws. PESA Act 1996 extends panchayat to tribal areas.
details.examTip: Fifth Schedule = Scheduled Areas (mainland tribal areas). Governor has special powers. TAC advises on tribal welfare.

rows.title: Tribal Areas in Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura, Mizoram
rows.articles: Administration of tribal areas in North-East
rows.keyPoints:
• Autonomous District Councils (ADCs) and Regional Councils
• ADCs have legislative, judicial, executive powers
• Can make laws on land, forests, marriage, social customs
• Exempted from many central and state laws

details.significance: High degree of autonomy to tribal areas in NE. Preserves tribal culture and customs. 10 ADCs across 4 states.
details.examTip: Sixth Schedule = 4 NE states (Assam, Meghalaya, Tripura, Mizoram). NOT Nagaland, Manipur, Arunachal (they have Art 371A type provisions).

rows.title: Distribution of Powers (Union, State, Concurrent Lists)
rows.articles: Union List 97, State List 66, Concurrent List 47 subjects
rows.keyPoints:
• **Union List**: Defence, foreign affairs, railways, banking, etc. (97 subjects)
• **State List**: Police, public health, agriculture, local govt (66 subjects; originally 47)
• **Concurrent List**: Education, forests, marriage, criminal law (47 subjects; originally 47)
• Residuary powers with Union (Art 248)

details.significance: Defines federal structure. Union List = Parliament only; State List = State Legislature only; Concurrent = Both (Union prevails in conflict).
details.examTip: Union List 97, State List 66, Concurrent 47. Residuary with Union. During Emergency, Union can legislate on State List (Art 250).

rows.title: Recognized Languages
rows.keyPoints:
• Originally 14 languages at commencement (1950)
• 21st Amendment (1967) added Sindhi
• 71st Amendment (1992) added Konkani, Manipuri, Nepali
• 92nd Amendment (2003) added Bodo, Dogri, Maithili, Santhali
• Total now: 22 languages

details.significance: Languages recognized for official purposes. Can be used in parliament, exams, etc. Official Language Commission considers these.
details.examTip: **22 languages** (originally 14 in 1950). Latest additions (2003): Bodo, Dogri, Maithili, Santhali. NO classical language status in 8th Schedule (separate designation).

rows.title: Land Reforms and Zamindari Abolition Acts
rows.keyPoints:
• Added by 1st Amendment 1951
• Provides immunity from judicial review to Acts placed in it
• Initially for land reforms, later misused for other Acts
• SC held (I.R. Coelho 2007): Acts violating basic structure can be reviewed

details.significance: Created to protect land reforms from being struck down. Later became controversial due to misuse. I.R. Coelho judgment limited its immunity.
details.examTip: 9th Schedule added by 1st Amendment 1951. Gives immunity from judicial review. I.R. Coelho case (2007) held: Basic structure cannot be violated even by 9th Schedule Acts.

rows.title: Anti-Defection Law
rows.articles: Provisions for disqualification on ground of defection
rows.keyPoints:
• Added by 52nd Amendment 1985
• MP/MLA disqualified if defects (voluntarily gives up membership or votes against party whip)
• Decision by Speaker/Chairman (subject to judicial review)
• Exception: Merger of 2/3rd members of party

details.significance: Curbs political defection. Ensures stability of government. However, gives excessive power to Speaker.
details.examTip: 52nd Amendment 1985 added 10th Schedule (Anti-Defection Law). Disqualification if: (1) voluntarily gives up membership (2) votes against party whip. Exception: 2/3rd merger.

rows.title: Powers of Panchayats
rows.keyPoints:
• Added by 73rd Amendment 1992
• 29 subjects devolved to Panchayats
• Includes: Agriculture, land reforms, minor irrigation, animal husbandry, fisheries, social forestry, drinking water, rural housing, poverty alleviation, primary education, health, women & child development

details.significance: Empowers Panchayats for rural development. State legislatures decide extent of devolution.
details.examTip: 73rd Amendment 1992 added 11th Schedule. 29 subjects for panchayats (e.g., agriculture, education, health). 3-tier system.

rows.title: Powers of Municipalities
rows.keyPoints:
• Added by 74th Amendment 1992
• 18 subjects devolved to Municipalities
• Includes: Urban planning, water supply, public health, slum improvement, fire services, urban forestry, safeguarding POW, regulation of slaughterhouses

details.significance: Empowers urban local bodies. State legislatures decide extent of devolution.
details.examTip: 74th Amendment 1992 added 12th Schedule. 18 subjects for municipalities (e.g., water supply, urban planning, health). 3 types: Nagar Panchayat, Municipal Council, Municipal Corporation.

data.summary: Indian Constitution has **25 Parts** and **12 Schedules**. **Most important**: Part III (FRs), Part IV (DPSPs), Part V (Union), Part VI (States), Part IVA (FDs - 42nd Amendment), Part IX (Panchayats - 73rd Amendment), Part IXA (Municipalities - 74th Amendment), Part XX (Amendment Art 368). **Key Schedules**: 7th (Union, State, Concurrent Lists), 8th (22 languages), 9th (Land reforms), 10th (Anti-defection - 52nd Amendment), 11th (Panchayats - 73rd Amendment), 12th (Municipalities - 74th Amendment). **Originally**: 395 Articles, 22 Parts, 8 Schedules. **Now**: 470 Articles (after 105 Amendments), 25 Parts, 12 Schedules.
